title: Facebook bans QAnon. They immediately pop up on Parler. Are the media giants just giving away market share? - Quora

response.answer_text: According to the dictionary, QAnon is the name of a convoluted, far-right, pro-Trump conspiracy believing that there is a deep state plot that is against President Donald Trump. The deep state refers to any unelected “shadow government” - military, intelligence, and government officials who try to secretly manipulate government. QAnon believes that Hollywood A-listers, leading philanthropists, Jewish financiers, Democrat politicians, and some other elite cabals covertly kidnap children, drain their blood, and cannibalizes them to gain mystical power. Only President Trump can bring the deep state down which is referred to as “The Storm” or “The Great Awakening” by QAnon’s disciples. QAnon is on a par with the Nazi cult rebranded, promoting racist, genocide, anti-Jewish Nazi terrorism. Jews kidnapped and slaughtered Christian children and drained their blood to mix in the dough for matzos consumed on Jewish holidays. QAnon considers that there is a secret cabal that controls high positions in government, banks, international finance, the news media, and the church and disarms the police, promotes homosexuality, and pedophilia. Even this pandemic and lockdown is due to the control behind by the evil child-trafficking cabal. Since its emergence in the US in 2017, QAnon is now spreading like California’s wildfires across the internet. It was reported that the membership of QAnon groups on Facebook increased by 120% in March, engagement rates increased by 91%, and 487,310 Facebook posts and 281,554 Instagram posts mentioning QAnon-related hashtags and phrases appeared. It all started on 4chan, a digital drain of hate speech and conspiracy theory. The adherents to it derive their beliefs from the cryptic postings of Q, an anonymous commenter who they believe to assist Donald Trump in his heroic fight against the Satanic pedophile Democrats. In 2019, the FBI labeled QAnon a domestic terror threat, observing that conspiracy theories have the potential to encourage “both groups and individual extremists to carry out criminal or violent acts”. Facebook and Twitter banned QAnon due to its violent content and political disinformation about the unfounded claims about the Democrats running a child-trafficking ring or presidential candidate Joe Biden abusing children to US voters. Facebook says QAnon content, represents an “identified Militarized Social Movement,” which is prohibited under its current rules. In other words, Facebook is reclassifying QAnon as no different than an extremist militia group, but not quite on the level of a terrorist organization or full-fledged hate group. Facebook writes. “We’ve been vigilant in enforcing our policy and studying its impact on the platform but we’ve seen several issues that led to today’s update. For example, while we’ve removed QAnon content that celebrates and supports violence, we’ve seen other QAnon content tied to different forms of real-world harm, including recent claims that the west coast wildfires were started by certain groups, which diverted the attention of local officials from fighting the fires and protecting the public.” Disseminating hate speech and violence on Facebook disobeys their community standards and is disallowed. It is not a matter of giving away of market share, but a rule, a regulation that must be followed.  Twitter and Facebook’s crackdown angered QAnon followers and they created accounts on the new right-wing oriented platform Parler. Parler, a free speech site, is an American social networking service that often posts far-right content, antisemitism, and conspiracy theories, having a significant user base of Trump supporters. It is popular among people who have been banned from mainstream social media networks. Thanks for reading.
